member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.Exception
member.summary: This is the base class for exceptions for the ILOG.Concert package.
member.remarks: All exceptions (other than RuntimeExceptions) thrown by a method of an IBM ILOG Concert Technology object are derived from this class.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.Exception.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates an exception with its corresponding message.
member.param: The message.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.Exception.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an exception without a message.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IAddable
member.summary: This interface is used for modeling objects.
member.remarks:
Objects of classes implementing this interface can be added to an instance of IModel. Constraint classes, such as IRange, and classes representing optimization objectives, such as IObjective, are examples.
All addable modeling objects can be assigned a name with the method setName(). The name can be queried with the method getName(). Assigning a name is not required. Modeling objects are created without an assigned name unless a name is specified in the construction.

member.name: P:ILOG.Concert.IAddable.Name
member.summary: Accesses/sets the name assigned to the invoking modeling object. If the invoking modeling object has not been assigned a name, null is returned.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IAnd
member.summary: This interface defines the API for classes that represent and-constraints.

remarks.p: An IAnd constraint is a multiple set of constraints. Objects of type IConstraint can be added to and removed from an instance of IAnd. The constraints in an and-constraint can be queried by the enumerator returned by the method enumerator.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.IAnd.Add(ILOG.Concert.IConstraint)
member.summary: This method adds the constraint to the invoking and-constraint.
member.param: The constraint to be added to the invoking instance of IAnd.
member.returns: The constraint that has been added.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.IAnd.Add(ILOG.Concert.IConstraint[])
member.summary: This method adds the array of constraints to the invoking and-constraint.
member.param: The array of constraints to be added to the invoking instance of IAnd.
member.returns: The array of constraints that have been added.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.IAnd.Add(ILOG.Concert.IConstraint[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This method adds constraints to the invoking instance of IAnd.

remarks.p: All objects implementing the IConstraint interface objects[start]...objects[start+num-1] are added to the invoking IAnd object.

member.param: The array of constraints to be added to the invoking instance of IAnd.
The first constraint to be added to the invoking instance of IAnd.
The number of constraints to be added to the invoking instance of IAnd.
member.returns: The array of constraints that have been added.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.IAnd.Remove(ILOG.Concert.IConstraint)
member.summary: This method removes the constraints from the invoking and-constraint.

remarks.p: If the constraint has been added multiple times, only one instance is removed from the and-constraint.

member.param: The constraint to be removed from the invoking instance of IAnd.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.IAnd.Remove(ILOG.Concert.IConstraint[])
member.summary: This method removes the array of constraints from the invoking and-constraint.
member.param: The array of constraints to be removed from the invoking IAnd.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.IAnd.Remove(ILOG.Concert.IConstraint[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This method removes constraints from the invoking instance of IAnd.

remarks.p: The constraints or, more precisely, the objects implementing the IConstraint interface objects[start]...objects[start+num-1] are removed from the invoking instance of IAnd. If a constraint has been added multiple times, only one instance is removed from the and-constraint.

member.param: The array of constraints to be removed from the invoking instance of IAnd.
The first constraints to be removed from the invoking instance of IAnd.
The number of constraints to be removed from the invoking instance of IAnd.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.IAnd.GetEnumerator
member.summary: This method returns an enumerator that traverses the constraints in the and-constraint.

remarks.p: Any manipulation of the and-constraint will render an enumerator accessed with this method invalid. An enumerator can be used only until the method Add, Remove, or Delete is called on the invoking instance of IAnd.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IConstraint
member.summary: This interface defines the API for constraints.
member.remarks: Instances of IConstraint are IAddable objects and can be added to an IModel. Not all modeling objects are instances of IConstraint, for example, IObjective is not a constraint. Examples of constraints are IRange and IloLPMatrix. IloLPMatrix is available to users of CPLEX.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.ICopyableVisitor
member.summary: A visitor of ICopyable. See ICopyable.VisitChildren for details.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.ICopyable
member.summary: This interface defines the API for elements of optimization models, such as variables, constraints, expressions, and objectives.
member.remarks: Objects of classes implementing this interface can be copied when needed to an application using IBM ILOG Concert Technology for .NET. All objects used for describing an optimization model implement this interface.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.ICopyable.MakeClone(ILOG.Concert.CloneManager)
member.summary: This method must be implemented so that it copies the invoking object to the engine of the given copy manager using the copy manager.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.ICopyable.VisitChildren(ILOG.Concert.ICopyableVisitor)
member.summary: This method is called when the object and all its sub-objects must be visited. To implement this method, you should first call the method ICopyableVisitor.BeginVisit() with yourself as parameter, then call ICopyableVisitor.VisitChild() for each sub-copyables, the call ICopyableVisitor.EndVisit() once again with yourself as parameter.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.CloneManager
member.summary: Manage copies of ICopyable objects.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IIntCollectionVar
member.summary: This interface defines the API for variable classes that can represent collections.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IIntExpr
member.summary: This is the basic public interface for integer expressions.
member.remarks:
Integer expressions are represented using objects of type IIntExpr. They are guaranteed to contain only variables of type integer and perform integer arithmetic. Integer expressions are created using integer variables and values with the numerical operations provided in IModeler.
Integer expressions and general expressions can be mixed. This is achieved by defining the interface IIntExpr as an extension of INumExpr. However, when an integer expression is used as an instance of INumExpr, the compile-time information is lost. For some optimizers, this will incur a runtime overhead because the type information needs to be regained at run time. This is documented for the optimizers where it is relevant.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IIntVar
member.summary: This interface defines the API for integer variables.

remarks.p: Objects of this type represent integer modeling variables.

Variables are characterized by their bounds and their type. The bounds can be changed after construction using the methods setLB() and setUB(). However, the type of a variable cannot be changed after construction. The type of an integer variable will be NumVarType.Int throughout its lifetime.

Variables may be assigned a name using the property Name(). The name can be queried in the same manner. Assigning a name is not required. By default, newly created variables will be created without an assigned name unless a name is specified in the construction.

Unlike other modeling objects of type IAddable, variables cannot be added directly to a model. Variables can only be part of a model implicitly, when they are used by another modeling object such as a constraint that has been added to the model.
Integer variables are generally created using any of the following methods. Note that Cplex is available to users of CPLEX(R).

Integer variables can also be created with the methods: IModeler.numVar(), IModeler.NumVarArray(), IloMPModeler.NumVar(), and IloMPModeler.NumVarArray() by passing a parameter to variable type NumVarType.Int or NumVarType.Bool. However, this causes the compile-time information about the type of the variable to be lost. This may incur a runtime overhead when used with certain optimizers. This is documented for the optimizers only where it is relevant.

As with numerical variables, INumVar integer variables can be created separately or in a column-wise way. This means that when a variable is created it is immediately installed in existing modeling objects. Use objects of type IColumn to achieve this.

member.name: P:ILOG.Concert.IIntVar.Min
member.summary: Accesses and sets the initial minimum value for this integer variable.

member.name: P:ILOG.Concert.IIntVar.Max
member.summary: Accesses and sets the initial maximum value for this integer variable.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.ILinearIntExpr
member.summary: This is the interface for scalar product expressions for integer variables.

remarks.para: Objects of type ILinearIntExpr represent integer linear expressions of the form

where x_i are variables of type IIntVar and c and a_i are integer values. Note that the variable types must be known at compile time for use with ILinearIntExpr. The java type of the variables must be IIntVar and cannot be INumVar with variable type NumVarType.Int.
ILinearIntExpr objects are created with the methods:
Once created, integer linear expressions can be fully edited:

ul.li: new terms a_i * x_i can be added;
coefficients of existing terms can be modified;

remarks.para: All the information stored in an ILinearIntExpr object can be queried. The constant term is accessed through the method getConstant(). The values and variables of the terms a_i * x_i are accessed using enumerator objects of type ILinearIntExpr.Enumerator that can be created using the method GetLinearEnumerator().

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.ILinearIntExpr.AddTerm(System.Int32,ILOG.Concert.IIntVar)
member.summary: Adds the new term coef * var to a scalar product.

remarks.p: No checks are performed to verify that the invoking ILinearIntExpr object does not contain a term with the same variable var. This method can create duplicate terms ... + a_i * x + ... + a_k * x + ... that could be joined to a single term ... + (a_i + a_k) * x + ....
Duplicates do not generate errors but require more memory and more running time when iterating through the terms of an ILinearIntExpr.

member.param: The coefficient of the added term.
The variable of the added term.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.ILinearIntExpr.Remove(ILOG.Concert.IIntVar)
member.summary: Removes a variable from the invoking ILinearIntExpr expression.
member.remarks: All terms in the invoking linear expression with the specified variable are removed from the invoking ILinearIntExpr object. If variable var occurs more than once in the invoking ILinearIntExpr, all occurrences are removed. The ILinearIntExpr.Enumerator can be used to remove individual terms regardless of duplicates.
member.param: The variable to be removed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.ILinearIntExpr.Remove(ILOG.Concert.IIntVar[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes a set of variables from the invoking ILinearIntExpr expression.
member.remarks: All terms in the invoking linear expression having any variable in var[start], ..., var[start+num-1] are removed. If variable var occurs more than once in the invoking ILinearIntExpr, all occurrences are removed. The ILinearIntExpr.Enumerator can be used to remove individual terms regardless of duplicates.
member.param: The array containing the variables to be removed.
The index of the first variable in var to be removed.
The number of variables in var to be removed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.ILinearIntExpr.Remove(ILOG.Concert.IIntVar[])
member.summary: Removes a set of variables from the invoking ILinearIntExpr expression.
member.remarks: All terms in the invoking linear expression having any variable in var[0], ..., var[num-1], where num is the length of array var, are removed from the invoking ILinearIntExpr object. If variable var occurs more than once in the invoking ILinearIntExpr, all occurrences are removed. The ILinearIntExpr.Enumerator can be used to remove individual terms regardless of duplicates.
member.param: The array of variables to be removed.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.ILinearIntExpr.GetLinearEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator for the variables in the invoking ILinearIntExpr expression.
member.remarks: An enumerator allows the caller to enumerate all the terms of an ILinearIntExpr and to perform simple operations such as querying or modifying a term. An enumerator also allows the caller to remove elements from the underlying ILinearIntExpr during the iteration with well-defined semantics.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IModel
member.summary: This interface defines the API for classes that represent optimization models.
member.remarks:
An IModel extractable is a multiple set of modeling objects, such as constraints or objectives. Objects of type IAddable can be added to and removed from an IModel. The modeling objects in a model can be queried using the enumerator returned by method GetEnumerator().
An important point is that optimizers such as CP or Cplex implement the IModel interface through its extension IModeler. The model associated with an optimizer is the model the optimizer will solve upon invocation of its method solve().

member.summary: This method adds the extractable object to the invoking model.

member.returns: The modeling object that has been added.

member.name: M:ILOG.Concert.IModel.GetEnumerator
member.summary: This method returns an enumerator that traverses the objects in the model.
member.remarks: Any manipulation of the model will render an enumerator accessed with this method invalid. An enumerator can only be used until the method add, remove or the method delete is called on the invoking IModel.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IModeler
member.summary: Interface for basic modeling.

remarks.p: IModeler defines an interface for building basic optimization models. This interface contains methods for constructing variables, basic constraints, and objective function objects. It is typically implemented by such optimizer classes as IloCplex, available in ILOG CPLEX. By using this interface rather than the actual implementation class, you can create optimization models that can be solved by any optimizer implementing the interface.

This interface is an extension of the IModel interface, and allows you to add modeling objects (instances of IAddable) to an IModeler object. For an optimizer implementing this interface, the model built corresponds to the model the optimizer will solve using its solve method.

There are two interfaces derived from IModeler: CP, available in CP Optimizer, and Cplex, available in CPLEX. CP defines the API for constraint-based engines. (An engine is an object whose function is to manipulate models that include variables and constraints.) Cplex is a modeling interface for Mathematical Programming. It adds support for several new modeling object interfaces, including LP matrices, semi-continuous variables, and special ordered sets (SOSs). It extends the functionality of IModeler to column-wise modeling and supports modification of variable types and expressions of ranged constraints and objective functions.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.INumExpr
member.summary: This is the public basic interface for all numerical expressions.
member.remarks:
Numerical expressions are represented by objects implementing this interface. They are constructed using the expression operator functions defined in the interface IModel or one of its extensions.
IBM ILOG Concert Technology distinguishes integer expressions that are built solely from integer variables and use only integer values. Integer expressions are represented by the interface IIntExpr, an extension of INumExpr. Integer expressions can be used wherever general expressions of type INumExpr are expected.
Variables defined by the interface INumVar or IIntVar are also extensions of INumExpr. Therefore, variables can be used wherever general expressions are expected.

members.member:
This interface defines the API for numerical variables of any type.
Objects implementing this interface are used to represent modeling variables in ILOG Concert Technology for Java. A modeling variable is characterized by its lower and upper bounds as well as by its type. Possible types are:
NumVarType.Float
NumVarType.Int
NumVarType.Bool
The bounds of a variable can be changed after the variable has been constructed, but its type remains fixed throughout the lifetime of the variable object.
@internal jconfig @internal opl

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IObjective
member.summary: This interface defines the API for objectives.
member.remarks:
An objective function is defined by an objective expression and an optimization sense. The objective sense is represented by ObjectiveSense objects and can be ObjectiveSense.Minimize or ObjectiveSense.Maximize.
Both the objective sense and expression can be queried and reset. In addition to this, the CPLEX class Cplex provides methods for manipulating linear objective expressions through its methods setLinearCoef() and setLinearCoefs(). Cplex is available to users of ILOG CPLEX.

member.summary: Sets the optimization expression to 0.

member.name: T:ILOG.Concert.IOr
member.summary: This interface defines the API for classes that represent or-constraints.

remarks.p: An instance of IOr (that is, an or-constraint) indicates that at least one of a set of constraints must be satisfied. Objects of type IConstraint can be added to and removed from an instance of IOr. The constraints in an or-constraint can be queried by the enumerator returned by method GetEnumerator().

members.member:
@internal jconfig
This is the interface for modeling objects representing ranged constraints of the format lb <= expr <= ub.
lb and ub are double values, referred to as the lower bound and upper bound of the ranged constraint, and expr is an expression. Values +- infinity can be used as bounds. This allows you to use IRange objects to represent more commonly used constraints:
for expr == rhs, set lb = ub = rhs
for expr <= rhs, set lb = -infinity and ub = rhs
for expr >= rhs, set lb = rhs and ub = infinity
Through the selection of lb and ub, constraints usually written as expr ~ rhs with ~ in <=, >=, or == can also be expressed. IRange objects can be constructed using a variety of methods defined for IModeler: AddRange(), AddEq(), AddLe(), AddGe(), Range(), Eq(), Le(), and Ge(). The methods of IRange allow you to query the expressions and bounds of a ranged constraint and to change its bounds or replace the expression. In addition to this, the CPLEX methods Cplex.SetLinearCoef() and Cplex.SetLinearCoefs() allow you to edit the constraint expression for the special case of a linear expression, as supported by Cplex. Cplex is available to users of ILOG CPLEX.

member.summary: Queries/sets the lower bound of the ranged constraints.

member.summary: Queries/sets the upper bound of the ranged constraints.

member.param: The new lower bound of the ranged constraints.
